Author: Ponchartrain; TNA
Title: SP 78/153/115: Pontchartrain to Hedges
Abstract Note: Sends a declaration [by Chasteaufort] and indicates its contents; hopes for remedy; contrasts condition of French prisoners in England with those of English prisoners in France. Date and place: 1704 Oct 20, Fontainebleau
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Pontchartrain; TNA
Title: SP 78/155/1: Pontchartrain to Sunderland
Abstract Note: Complains of very harsh treatment of prisoners, especially those at Plymouth and Kinsale. Suggests that men imprisoned there more than one year should return to France in exchange for same number of English prisoners. Contrasts the harsh treatment in British prisons with the humane treatment of British prisoners of war in France.  Date and place: 1710 June 4, Marly.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Craggs; TNA
Title: SP 78/168/57: Craggs to Sutton
Abstract Note: Instructs him to intercede for French Protestants in France, who he asserts represent no threat to the French state in contrast to the Catholics in Britain, most of whom are Jacobites. Date and place: 1720 July 4/15, Whitehall.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Rondeau; TNA
Title: SP 91/11: Rondeau to Newcastle
Abstract Note: Further to f.132 Count Wratislaw now has three more pictures of the Emperor, set with diamonds, for the present German and Courland favourites. They were originally intended for the Princes Dolgorukov, who are disgraced a second time and sent to Siberia. Czarina feared that gentlemen who visited them in their first exile might raise rebellion against her. Persian ambassador, now recalled, achieved nothing because it is said he would not treat on former instructions when he heard Prince Tamas was in posession of Ispahan, and may contract with Ottoman government to drive Russians out of province of Ghilan, desirable to both the Grand Seigneur and the Sophy, whose subjects had a great silk trade with that province, before Russian conquest which ruined it. In this event Russia might wage war on the Turks keeping them fully employed at home and unable to assist the Emperor. Duke of Liria annoyed that recall of Prince Scerbatov, the Russian minister in Spain, so secret. Obvious that Russia has taken this step only on the persuasion of Vienna. Duke says his king should recall him too. Count Wratislaw and Russians hindered by duke from assisting Emperor in case a war should break out. Plea for immediate character similar to that of Ward. Congratulations to Czarina would be kindly received by this court and a mortification to that of Vienna.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Anon.; TNA
Title: SP 36/5/177: Examination of Phillis Leveridge, living at Richard Wagget's in Aldersgate Street
Abstract Note: She says she had the two books entitled 'A new miscellany of Court Songs', part 1 and part 2 and the single half sheet, entitled 'Two New Ballads' from a woman named Anne Bowes and that she usually sits at the Temple Gate to sell such books and often goes to the coffee-houses about Temple Bar to sell them. Papers annexed. Two New Ballads. Printed. Two copies. [Delafaye's] notes on James Watson and the Court Songs above mentioned. The first part was only the dispute between Sir Robert Walpole and Mr.Pulteny.      The second part he was infatuated to go so far as the ballad about the King's speech. [See Two New Ballads}. He had that about the King's speech from Bingley - Bishop of Rochester's plot.      Lord's address - had from Ozindo. Bingley lives in Mist's house and corrects for Mist - sometimes Watson does it - Bingley has no capacity for writing .... Printed 500 of the Occasional Writer for Gun Jones. It was printed before - supposed at the Duke of Bedford's house, where there was a printing press a long time. There part of the 'State of the debts of the Nation' was printed, and the Emperor's Memorial - printed Shippen's speech for Mist.      History of the 'Full of Count Olivarez' was done by one Kelly in the Fleet - a West Indian who understands Spanish, Italian and French - he gets his living by translating. 'Now or 'Never' written by Roderick Mackenzie - mentioned in Layer's report. The Hotchpotch, written by Kelly.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Almon, John; TNA
Title: TS 11/177/765: Rex versus John Almon, bookseller. Publishing libel entitled `Junius's letter to the King' in The London Museum of Politics Miscellanies and Literature. Court: King's Bench
Abstract Note: The said Defendant John Almon maketh oath that the Number of the Books of the London Museum Number one sent to this Depon_Shop (?) on the 1st of Jan/ry last appears by one of his Shop Books to be three hundred and this Deponent verily believes to the best of his recollection that he ordered the Sale of the London Museum and of all the Monthly Magazines published on that day to be stopped on some part of the first day of January and that the Number of the London Museum sold before he ordered the Sale to be stopped as far as this Deponent is able to ascertain was sixty seven or sixty eight. John Miller of Queens Head passage pater Noster Row London maketh oath that he has carefully looked among his paperes for the Note or Letter with this Depon/t rem/bers to have re/ced from the above Defendant John Almon on the first day of January last to the best of this Deponents recollection expressing his the said Def/ts disapprobation of his Name being put to the blue cover of the London Museum Numer one, but this Dep/t cannot find the same and verily believes it is totally lost and was most probably torn as a paper not likely to be of any consequence and this Depon/t well remembers that the said Def/t Almon came to this Dep/t on the 2nd or 3rd day of the same Month of January to the best of this Deponents Recollection and declared to him that he would not sell the said London Museum on Account of the Letter of Iunius being inserted therein unless he would take out the said Letters which on the said Books being sent back to him this Deponent he accordingly did and placed as the last leaf a Catalogue of Books instead thereof and this Deponent also altered the blue Cover and omitted the said Defend/ts Name thereon. Thomas Adams servant to the above Defend/t Mr John Almon maketh oath that he is the only Sevant employed in the Shop of the said Def/t and this Deponent saith that to the best of his Rem/brance when Number one of the London Museum was sent in to his said Master’s the said Dedendants Haouse on the first day of Jan/ry last He the said Def/t was not at home but that on his Return home he did in the afternoon of the same day as this Dep/t verily bel/s Order this Depon/t not to sell the London Museum or any of the Monthly Magazines published on that day and in particular the said Def/t ordered the several Books of the London Museum to be taken out of the Shop and they were accordingly the next Morning by or before 8 o’clock carried up into one of the store garrets of the said Defendants House by this Dep/t and in a very few days afterwards this Deponent by the Defendants order put them all in a Bag and carried them to Mr Millers And this Deponent saith that to the best of his knowledge and remembrance and as he verily believes from the (heart?) they were so carried up stairs on the Morning after they were brought in to the (time) they were so carried back to Mr Millers by this Deponent they were not touched or any taken away nor did this Deponent to the best of his knowledge sell one after his s/d Master had so forbid the Sale as aforesaid

Archive Location: Treasury Solicitor and HM Procurator General, Papers

Author: Treasury Solicitor; TNA
Title: TS Division 1: General and miscellaneous records of the Treasury Solicitor and HM Procurator General
Abstract Note: Scope and Content General and miscellaneous records relating to the work of the department.  General case papers are in TS 11, TS 18 and TS 22, while those in prize and prize bounty cases are in TS 13. Registers of divorce cases in TS 29. Law Officers' and Counsel's opinions are in TS 25  Prosecutions following the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745 are in TS 20, with those for seditious libel in TS 24, and war crimes, in TS 26. Claims to peerages are in TS 16. TS 36 contains court proceedings and manuscripts of cases dealt with by the Treasury Solicitor on behalf of the Crown. Royal wills, TS 86.  Manorial documents in TS 19 and deeds in TS 21 are documents which came into the hands of the Treasury Solicitor in the course of his duties, as did some surviving records from the Court of Survey for London in TS 47  Miscellaneous records including reports books, letter books, and assignation books are in TS 3, TS 5, TS 8, TS 9 and TS 15. Accounts are in TS 7. Registered files are in TS 27. Establishment and management papers of the Treasury Solicitor's Department are in TS 60. Staff instructional guides, etc, are in TS 78  TS 23 is a collection of miscellanea that includes copies of royal correspondence from the seventeenth century.  Records of the War Trade Intelligence Department, transferred to HM Procurator General for Prize Court purposes, are in TS 14.  Records relating to restrictive practices and resale prices are in TS 83.

Author: Treasury Solicitor; TNA
Title: TS 20: Jacobite Rebellion (1745) Prosecution Papers
Abstract Note: Treasury Solicitor's papers, including some formerly part of what is now TS 11, concerning the prosecution mainly in England, but also in Scotland, of those involved in the 1745 Jacobite rebellion. The series includes correspondence, administrative papers, lists of rebels, prisoners and witnesses, evidence, and records of assizes and special commissions and of proceedings against Scottish peers. Prison records and lists of rebels may give names and other details, such as age, place of birth, trade, regiment in which served, if dead since capture, etc. Prison conditions are sometimes indicated, including the presence of women and children, and similar information may be obtained from the correspondence of the agents of John Sharpe, the Treasury Solicitor (e.g. Stratford Eyre).

Author: Stieler, Georg
Title: Leibniz als Politiker und Volkserzieher

Author: Schuhmann, Karl
Title: Leibniz' Briefe an Hobbes
Abstract Note: This article discusses Leibniz's two letters to Hobbes. The first one was not passed on to Hobbes, whereas the second one remained an unfinished draft. In his letters, Leibniz defends Hobbes against attacks that make no distinction between the abstract, general content of his theory and its application to concrete cases. On the other hand, Leibniz criticizes Hobbes as well. Against Hobbes' psychology, Leibniz contends that the idea of sense perception as a reaction that lingers on in the body is impossible without assuming the existence of a soul (which Hobbes denies). However, Leibniz misconstrues Hobbes' notion of reaction as actual motion instead of a tendency to motion, as Hobbes has it. Leibniz's further argument that material cohesion cannot be understood as a reaction to the impact of other bodies is also flawed since it only considers one body and not two, as is necessary for any reaction to take place.

Author: Bressler und Aschenburg, Ferdinand Ludwig von
Title: Das Heutige Engelland/ Nebst dessen incorporirten zwey Königreichen Schott- und Irrland
Abstract Note: Der Erste, der als Förderer von Dichtung und Kunst genannt wird, war Ludwig Ferdinand von Breßler und Aschenburg (*04.07.1681 †07.05.1722), der sich als Übersetzer betätigte und landesgeschichtliche und genealogische Studien verfasste. Ab 1699 hat er in Halle und Leipzig Rechtswissenschaften, Physik, Politik und Geschichte studiert und war nach einer Studienreise durch England und Holland 1707 in seine Heimatstadt Breslau zurückgekehrt. Hier begann seine Ratskarriere als Römisch-Kaiserlicher Rat, Kommerzienrat und Breslauer Unterkämmerer. 1712 Heiratete er in zweiter Ehe die Österreicherin Marianne Elisabeth von Wirth (*1690 †1728). Um Ludwig Ferdinand von Breßler und Aschenburg hat sich ein bürgerlicher Kreis humanistischer Gelehrter gebildet, zu dem auch der für seine leidenschaftliche Liebeslyrik bekannte Johann Christian Günther Zugang hatte. Marianne Elisabeth von Breßler gehörte zu den großen Gönnerinnen Günthers, wofür er den Breßlers einige Gedichte widmete.
Series: Die Heutigen Christlichen Souverainen von Europa, Das ist: Ein kurtzer Genealogischer und Politischer Abriß/ Darinnen des Heil. Röm. Reiches/ aller Königreiche/ Staaten und Souverainen Fürsten von Europa Historische Haupt-Periodi; die ietzt allda lebenden Potentaten und Regenten mit ihren Angehörigen; die in selbigen Orten befindlichten vornehmsten Ertz- und Bistümer; wie auch gar viele bey Höfen/ in ansehnlichen Collegiis, in wichtigen Gouvernemens und in höchsten Kriegs-Diensten stehende Beamten; Nebst Jeden Landes angehängten berühmten Familien, Ritter-Orden/ Societäten und hin und wieder subsistirenden Gesandten nach geographischer Ordnung vorgestellet werden/

Author: O'Hara, James G.
Title: Leibniz and the Jacobite War: Reports and Reflections on the Battle of the Boyne and Events in Ireland, 1689-91
Publication Title: Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy. Section C: Archaeology, Celtic Studies, History, Linguistics, Literature
Abstract Note: Among the manuscript papers and letters of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646-1716) that are preserved chiefly at the Niedersächsische Landesbibliothek in Hanover and are being published by the Academy of Sciences in Berlin are a number of documents relating to the Jacobite War in Ireland of 1689-91. The intention of this paper is to direct attention to and discuss these items, consisting of a series of passages in Leibniz's political and historical correspondence and a hitherto unnoticed eye-witness account of the Battle of the Boyne. The former, paraphrased in English, are incorporated in the text, whereas the latter is given in full translation. In presenting this material it is hoped to provide an insight into the interest of Leibniz, polyhistor and one of the greatest scholars of seventeenth- and early eighteenth-century Europe, in Ireland and Irish civilisation.
Journal Abbreviation: Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy. Section C: Archaeology, Celtic Studies, History, Linguistics, Literature

Author: Happel, Eberhard Werner
Title: Fortuna Brittannica, oder Brittannischer Glücks-Wechsel .... [Theil 1], Fürstellend Eine kurtzbündige Beschreibung aller Königen von Engelland, und des schier stets unglückseeligen Hauses Stuart : insonderheit aber den ausführlichen Lebens-Lauf Caroli II und des ... Königs Jacobi II ... fortgesetzet bis zur Erhebung des jetzigen grossmächtigen Königs Wilhelm von Oranie ... / von Everhardo Guernero Happelio
Abstract Note: Eberhard Werner Happel (* 12. August 1647 in Kirchhain, Hessen; † 15. Mai 1690 in Hamburg) war ein deutscher Universalgelehrter, Übersetzer, Romanautor und Journalist. Inhaltsverzeichnis     1 Leben     2 Werke (Auswahl)     3 Literatur     4 Weblinks Leben Der Sohn eines evangelisch-lutherischen Pastors studierte ab 1663 Mathematik und Medizin, später auch Jura in Marburg. 1668 ging er nach Magdeburg, später nach Hamburg. 1674–1679 war er in Holstein angestellt, danach kehrte er nach Hamburg zurück und lebte dort als Lehrer und Schriftsteller. Er schrieb umfangreiche höfisch-galante Geschichtsromane, von denen der um 1690 entstandene Akademische Roman, worinnen das Studentenleben fürgebildet ist als zeitgeschichtliches Bild des Studentenlebens nach dem Dreißigjährigen Krieg von besonderem Interesse ist. Daneben trat er als Übersetzer des Valerius Maximus und Autor historischer Werke, insbesondere der Relationes curiosae, hervor, einer der frühesten deutschen Zeitschriften mit breitem populärwissenschaftlichem Interesse.

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/60/173: To Cresset
Abstract Note: Folio 173. To Cresset. Acknowledges letters, one from Celle, of Dec 21 and one from Hanover, of Dec 29. Explains delay of his reply: he had to deal, as a matter of urgency, with a packet of papers received from Paget. Gives a precis of Paget's dispatch of Oct 2 [1693, see f.168, ante] and comments sharply on the raising of the siege of Belgrade. - Asks Cresset to thank the electoress Sophia for her appreciative interest in himself. - Describes his audience of the electoress of Saxony from her sick-bed. - There is a rumour of [Benoit Bidal, baron] d'Asfeld coming to Dresden 'to show favours'. At his, Stepney's, behest, Ilten sounded the elector, but is satisfied that d'Asfeld, 'that accomplice of [Sieur Barthélemy de Livières] Grandval' will get no encouragement. - To-day is 'Ausschuss-or Deputationstag', i.e. deputies of the political estates of the electorate will meet in committee, at which Gersdorff will propose a 'further supply' in the elector's name. Stepney does not think that the degree of their compliance will be 'proportionable' to the elector's 'wants or expectations'. - [Bodo von] Oberg [Hanoverian diplomat] is on his way to Vienna. PS. Warmly recommends [? William] Storer (see ff.11v and 33v, ante) whom Cresset has taken into his service and whom, he says, he has known for seven years. - Acknowledges letter of Jan 5. - The [French] peace proposal is justly ridiculed wherever it is considered, particularly by the electo [of Saxony]. - Regarding the 'inclinations of the elector of Bavaria, Leibniz will tell him, Cresset, what Stepney, when asked about his opinion, intimated to him ten months ago, namely 'I gave it for whoring.... He has something of King Charles's humour & I believe for a mistriss would reject not only the Netherlands but even the reversion of the kingdome of Spain if France would offer that likewise as a bait for a peace...' . Date and Place: 1694 Jan 12/22 Dresden
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: State Papers Foreign, Archives of British Legations

Author: Sallust
Title: The war with Catiline; The war with Jugurtha
Abstract Note: "Sallust, Gaius Sallustius Crispus (86-35 BCE), a Sabine from Amiternum, acted against Cicero and Milo as tribune in 52, joined Caesar after being expelled from the Senate in 50, was restored to the senate by Caesar and took part in his African campaign as praetor in 46, and was then appointed governor of New Africa (Numidia). Upon his return to Rome he narrowly escaped conviction for malfeasance in office, retired from public life, and took up historiography. Sallust's two extant monographs take as their theme the moral and political decline of Rome, one on the conspiracy of Catiline and the other on the war with Jugurtha. Although Sallust is decidedly unsubtle and partisan in analyzing people and events, his works are important and significantly influenced later historians, notably Tacitus. Taking Thucydides as his model but building on Roman stylistic and rhetorical traditions, Sallust achieved a distinctive style, concentrated and arresting; lively characterizations, especially in the speeches; and skill at using particular episodes to illustrate large general themes"--Publisher website

Author: Strickland, Lloyd
Title: The Philosophy of Sophie, Electress of Hanover
Abstract Note: In philosophical circles, Electress Sophie of Hanover (1630-1714) is known mainly as the friend, patron, and correspondent of Leibniz. While many scholars acknowledge Sophie's interest in philosophy, some also claim that Sophie dabbled in philosophy herself, but did not do so either seriously or competently. In this paper I show that such a view is incorrect, and that Sophie did make interesting philosophical contributions of her own, principally concerning the nature of mind and thought.

Author: Wigelsworth, JEFFREY R.
Title: Deism in Enlightenment England: Theology, politics, and Newtonian public science
Abstract Note: This is the first complete study of English deists as a group in several decades and it argues for a new interpretation of deism in the English Enlightenment. While there have been many recent studies of the deist John Toland, the writings of other contemporary deists have been forgotten. With extensive analysis of lesser known figures such as Anthony Collins, Matthew Tindal, Thomas Chub, and Thomas Morgan, in addition to unique insights into Toland, *Deism in Enlightenment England * offers a much broader assessment of what deism entailed in the eighteenth century. Readers will see how previous interpretations of English deists, which place these figures on an irreligious trajectory leading towards modernity, need to be revised. This book uses deists to address a number of topics and themes and theme in English history and will be of particular interest to scholars of Enlightenment history, history of science, theology and politics, and the early modern era.

Author: Rose, Jacqueline
Title: Godly Kingship in Restoration England. The Politics of the Royal Supremacy, 1660 - 1688
Abstract Note: Jacqueline Rose sees both the English Reformation and the Restoration as contexts for supremacy. This is why she analyses the ideology of royal supremacy in a wider context and goes back to the establishment of the 'reformed' English monarchy in the years 1530 to 1547. Then she continues to analyse the clashes of crown and parliament in the 17th century as well as the crown's relation to early-modern lawyers. The book finally describes the connections of spiritual authority and royal jurisdiction. The role of Anglican bishops is discussed alongside dissenting and anti-clerical movements in England. "Hunting Hobbists" (p. 221) is an especially provocative chapter on the suppression of political oppositions. And the final comments on "papist caesaropapism" (p. 229-274) under James II can also contribute to fervent discussions.

Title: The war of parties and waste of the national resources, with a peep into the policy of European cabinets: or The history and mystery of increasing taxation, commercial difficulties, pauperism and crime, since the revolution of 1688, in a series of dialogues between John Bull and Brother Jonathan : In this work, to be continued in parts, will be developed a plan for easing the national burdens and improving the condition of the agricultural , commercial, and manufacturing classes.

Author: Harris, Tim
Title: Politics under the later Stuarts: party conflict in a divided society, 1660-1715
Abstract Note: The author gives a well-written and unbiased introduction into party politics of the 17th and early 18th century and points out that the Whig versus Tory conflict cannot be equated to the country versus court conflict. (page 9) The author also tries to see the 1688 Revolution in the light of party politics, parliament and constitutional settlement and shows that the Glorious Revolution tackled questions which had already been resolved in the Pax Westfalica for continental Europe in the mid-17th century. (page 54) The book is especially useful as a basic introduction for graduate students.

Author: Clifton, Robin
Title: The last popular rebellion: the western rising of 1685
Abstract Note: This book is a very important attempt to see the Monmouth Rebellion not just as a foreshadow of 1688, but rather as a turning point in the entire history of early modern British rebellions. In contrast to earlier studies, it especially focuses on the towns people and peasants who joined the Duke's army. The men supporting Monmouth came from many different social and professional groups and represented a new idea of government: a legitimate leader has to be "the best men in the country"! page 287: It lay behind a statement made in a Portsmouth tavern during the rebellion, that the Duke 'had a great force (with him) ... and he was a true Protestant. Here emphasis fell upon the religious qualification, but Monmouth won support too because of his broader attributes. An Oxford boatman in 1683 called him 'the best man in the kingdom' in the context of talk concerning the Duke's right to the throne. This speaker may have heard CONTRACTUAL THEORIES of government argued by ables theorists than himself, for a Fellow of Lincoln College, Oxford, was accused of helping incite a pro-Monmouth riot in that town during April 1683 (to which the boatman quoted above also contributed), by making a remarkable statement in an Oxford tavern. (...) Contract theory had been the very essence of Leveller propaganda in the 1640s, and had reappeared during the Exclusion debates."

Author: NLA HA
Title: Cal. Br. 24, 2984: Konzept eines Schreibens Kurfürst Ernst Augusts an den Residenten Hüneken im Haag wegen Glückwunsch zur Dämpfung des Aufstandes in England
Abstract Note: Verhältnis des Fürstentums Calenberg-Göttingen bzw. des Kurfürstentums/Königreichs Hannover zu den verschiedenen deutschen Reichsständen und zu den europäischen Staaten:  Der Bestand Cal. Br. 24 Äußere Angelegenheiten wurde in der Zeit von März bis August 1948 von dem Angestellten Lathwesen unter Leitung des Unterzeichneten neu verzeichnet, nachdem das alte Findbuch infolge Bombenangriffs im Oktober 1943 durch Brand vernichtet worden war. Dieser Bestand überschneidet sich in vielen Fällen mit der Abteilung Hann. 9 (Ministerium der Äußeren Angelegenheiten), so dass beide Designationen nebeneinander bearbeitet werden müssten. Allerdings ist der größte Teil von Hann. 9 während des Krieges 1939/45 durch Feindeinwirkung vernichtet worden. Die Unterabteilung Österreich ist im Gegensatz zu sämtlichen anderen Abteilungen nach Sachbetreffen in sich unterteilt und dementsprechend in einem eigenen Band des Findbuches, allerdings in der alphabetischen Reihenfolge des Gesamtbestandes, vereinigt. Die Hauptmasse dieser Designation bilden Akten der regierenden Fürsten und der Geheimen Räte zu Hannover, denen indessen auch andere Provenienzen (Handakten der Minister und Gesandten) angeschlossen wurden. In der Abteilung Österreich ist außerdem noch das außerordentlich wertvolle Archiv der hannoverschen Gesandtschaft in Wien enthalten. Bei der Neuordnung dieses umfangreichen Bestandes, an der mehrere Hände mitgewirkt haben, sind außerdem noch aus anderen Aktenabteilungen einzelne Faszikel herausgelöst und hier eingegliedert worden, da sie sich inhaltsmäßig in den bereits vorhanden gewesenen Akten einfügen. Neu aufgenommen in dieses Findbuch wurden von Staatsarchiv-Referendar Dr. Mundhenke bearbeitete Regesten von Urkunden, deren Abschriften bei der Verzeichnung festgestellt wurden. (In der Abt. Österreich befinden sich solche Abschriften). Bei genauer Durchsicht der Aktenstücke würden sich sicherlich noch weitere Urkundenabschriften vorfinden. Infolge Zeitmangels war dieses jedoch unter den gegenwärtigen Verhältnissen nicht möglich. Die Regesten wurden in einem chronologischen Verzeichnis der besseren Übersicht wegen zusammengefaßt. Hannover, den 01. September 1948 gez. Dr. Diestelkamp

Author: Worsley, Henry; TNA
Title: SP 89/25/14: Henry Worsley to Paul Methuen
Abstract Note: Acknowledges receipt of dispatches relating to the discovery of a Jacobite plot and arrest of the Swedish Count Gyllemberg in London. Has informed Portuguese Court and encloses Secretary of State's congratulatory answer (f.26), which contrasts with marked silence of Spanish and French ambassadors. Spanish naval preparations, probably in support of a Jacobite rising. Portuguese squadron of six sail being prepared to support Venetians at Corfu against the Turks. Encloses correspondence concerning the quarrel between the Portuguese and Spanish Crowns over the seizure of two Buenos Aires ships [in 1704] and claim for 600,000 pieces-of-eight (ff.28-55). Death of Dutch envoy, Mr. Schonenberg, after a long illness. Bad weather and resulting shipwrecks. Naval news.  Date and place: 1717 Mar 21, NS Lisbon.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew

Author: Curry, Thomas; TNA
Title: HO 42/37/195: Copy of resolutions, printed by J. Stead of Gosport [Hampshire] from a meeting chaired by Thomas Curry, Magistrate, and signed by over 450 people
Abstract Note: The resolutions affirm the loyalty of the inhabitants of the Borough of Gosport and the parish of Alverstoke, Hampshire to the monarch, the country and the legal system. The signatories agree to five resolutions:  (1) to cooperate with others to preserve their liberty, property and constitution against republicans and levellers,  (2) to discover and punish those involved in seditious publications, and to discourage seditious thought,  (3) to pass on anything they hear which might be seditious to the Justices of the Peace,  (4) to assist the magistrates in putting down any riots or illegal assemblies, so to restore the public peace,  (5) that they pledge themselves and all they have to the preservation of the King and the constitution.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: Home Office: Domestic Correspondence, George III

Author: The National Archives
Title: State papers domestic 1547-1649
Abstract Note: The state papers domestic are the accumulated papers of the secretaries of state relating to home affairs. Theycontain information on every facet of early modern government, including social and economic affairs, law and order, religious policy, crown possessions and intelligence gathering as well as some references to foreign policy. They can also include private and official letters, musters, reports, commissions and instructions, council orders and correspondence, memoranda and draft parliamentary bills. The state papers were frequently treated as private property by some secretaries of state who incorporated 'state papers' into their own private collections. As a result state papers can be found in numerous other archives, most notably the Lansdowne, Harleian and Cottonian collections of the British Library and those at Hatfield House.
Type: The National Archives  Kew Richmond Surrey TW9 4DU Tel: +44 (0) 20 8876 3444

Author: Court of King's Bench; TNA
Title: KB 10: Court of King's Bench: Crown Side: London and Middlesex Indictments Files
Abstract Note: Scope and Content King's Bench indictment files covering London and Middlesex only. There are some gaps before 1702, but from that date the series is almost complete. They have an internal filing order, beginning with indictments brought into court on writs of certiorari, then Middlesex indictments, presentments, informations by the master of the Crown Office and informations ex officio. The files do not include a very large amount of London material, and what there is consists of indictments brought into King's Bench on writs of certiorari and informations. It may be that London was included in the same file as Middlesex because of the similar lengths of the periods during which writs had to be returned to the court; it bore the same relationship to King's Bench as other counties. The Middlesex material includes presentments made by petty constables, including those for the liberty of Westminster, to two grand juries, one for Ossulstone hundred and one for the rest of the county, for minor offences; indictments in the first instance, mostly cases of assault rather than felonies, received as a result of the court's overriding jurisdiction in the county by virtue of its residence there; indictments, recognizances, special verdicts and summary convictions removed from inferior jurisdictions under certiorari; and criminal informations, especially informations by the master of the Crown Office and by the attorney general (informations ex officio).
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: Record of the Court of King's Bench and other courts: Crown side records

Author: Worsley, Henry; TNA
Title: SP 89/23/114: Henry Worsley to James Stanhope
Abstract Note: Petition of Bristol merchants over the loss of the Carter Galley lost in bad weather when forced out of Recife by the Governor's order. He will ask for satisfaction but unlikely to get any until further information available from Pernambuco. Toby Bourk (f.238) has arrived but not yet done anything much. Departure of Padre Cienfuegos with pictures for the Emperor of Germany, despite Portuguese efforts to impound them as not yet paid for. Increase in pro-French feeling at Court and why. King has returned from Azeitão in good health.  Date and place: 1715 July 19, NS Lisbon.

Author: List and Index Society; Public Record Office London
Title: State Papers Domestic. George I (S.P. 35). Index to Lists Parts I to IV. 1714-1727
Abstract Note: The List and Index Society is a not-for-profit society that publishes editions and calendars of historical records. It has also published monographs from time to time. Its publications can be found in the major British and American public and university libraries: they are also available for purchase by individuals. The society is managed by its officers and a council representing the British historical community. When Sir Geoffrey Elton and others founded the Society in 1965, its aim was to meet an immediate need by publishing and distributing ‘photographic copies of unprinted lists and indexes kept in the Public Record Office, London, and of other unprinted guides and aids to the use of public archives in the British Isles', so that historians working at a distance from London could find out what was available in advance of their visits. As the Society nears its half-century, the dissemination of lists and indexes in facsimile has been replaced by the online catalogue. In these very different circumstances, the Society continues to serve the historical community by publishing texts, editions and tabulations of historical manuscripts that are outside the range of the online catalogue, but judged to be unremunerative by academic and other presses.
Manual Tags: diplomacy; England; Great Britain; intelligence; Ireland; proclamation; Scotland; state papers; Wales

Author: Hoppit, Julian
Title: Land of Liberty? : England 1689-1727
Abstract Note: This study sees England as country of contested but nevertheless increasing liberty and comprimise. (page 9: "an increasing (if still incomplete) willingsness towards accomodation and compromise that allowed rival views to coexist") But it is not quite clear how the author evaluates the crown as a government institution and the individual contribution of the Monarch.  On page 49, the author condemns George I as an inefficient ruler, but like many other anglophone researchers, he totally neglects that being German is more than 'not being able to speak English'. It implies different training as a ruler and different perceptions of monarchical rule. This is something I would like to stress in my own thesis.

Title: Liberty's last squeak; containing An elegiac ballad, An ode to an informer [&c.] by Peter Pindar, esq.
English Historical Documents, 1783-1832
Abstract Note: "English Historical Documents is the most comprehensive, annotated collection of documents on British (not in reality just English) history ever compiled. Conceived during the Second World War with a view to ensuring the most important historical documents remained available and accessible in perpetuity, the first volume came out in 1953, and the most recent volume almost sixty years later. The print series, edited by David C. Douglas, is a magisterial survey of British history, covering the years 500 to 1914 and including around 5,500 primary sources, all selected by leading historians Editors. It has over the years become an indispensable resource for generations of students, researchers and lecturers. EHD is now available in its entirety online. Bringing EHD into the digital age has been a long and complex process. To provide you with first-rate, intelligent searchability, Routledge have teamed up with the Institute of Historical Research (one of the research institutes that make up the School of Advanced Study, University of London http://www.history.ac.uk) to produce EHD Online. The IHR's team of experts have fully indexed the documents, using an exhaustive historical thesaurus developed by the Royal Historical Society for its Bibliography of British and Irish History. The sources include treaties, statutes, declarations, government and cabinet proceedings, military dispatches, orders, acts, sermons, newspaper articles, pamphlets, personal and official letters, diaries and more. Each section of documents and many of the documents themselves are accompanied by editorial commentary. The sources cover a wide spectrum of topics, from political and constitutional issues to social, economic, religious as well as cultural history."--[Résumé de l'éditeur].

Author: Burgh, William; TNA
Title: HO 42/34/42: Letter from William Burgh of York dissociating the writer and a majority of the householders of York from a petition to the House of Commons purporting to represent the view of the Corporation of York and praying for a speedy peace
Abstract Note: The letter reports that 2 factions are now obtaining signatures to rival addresses to the king and accuses the opposition of enticing children and paupers to sign with the contents concealed. Enclosed is a printed copy of the petition supported by Burgh as an address from a general meeting of inhabitants moved by the recorder and seconded by the Reverend John Preston of Askham. The petition assures the king of their 'zeal and attachment to the present constitution', confidence in 'Royal wisdom most conducive to the safety and protection of this country against all its foreign and domestic enemies' and trusts in the restoration of an honourable peace.

Author: HM Procurator General and Treasury Solicitor; Treasury Solicitor; TNA
Title: TS 24: Miscellaneous Papers on Sedition Cases (Official correspondence and other material relating to prosecutions for seditious libel by the Treasury Solicitor since 1790)
Abstract Note: The papers (some formerly part of what is now TS 11) in the main reflect the activities of various societies who were concerned about freedom of speech and parliamentary reform during the 1790s and the second decade of the nineteenth century. The greater part of the series consists of printed pamphlets and newspapers in which inflammatory and seditious writings appeared, but there are also some in-letters and out-letters of the London Corresponding Society. Many of the late-eighteenth-century papers, such as printed pamphlets, newspapers, etc, are annotated or endorsed by Edward Lanzun, the King's Messenger responsible for their seizure. There are also some papers, 1900 to 1901, including a broadsheet, issued in connection with the campaign against the war in South Africa by the Stop-the-War Committee.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: Treasury Solicitor: Miscellaneous Papers on Sedition Cases

Author: Davis, Natalie Zemon
Title: The rites of violence: religious riot in 16th-century France
Abstract Note: Since the publication of ‘The Rites of Violence’, historians of early modern France have explored the character of different forms of violence. Not all of these examinations have reacted to Davis's clarion call to heed the influence of religion in everyday life, but they should nonetheless be considered as they have helped to develop a better understanding of early modern violence as well as to inform more recent studies of religious violence.3 One aspect of this research has questioned the grand narrative of Norbert Elias's ‘civilizing process’ and the evidence for a decline in violence in the early modern period. The transformation of the duel might be regarded as indicative of this process as it changed from being a judicial and public encounter to a private means of resolving disputes which was subject to increasing anti-duelling legislation. In recent studies, however, duelling has been seen together with feuding and revenge killings as matters of honour with their own particular codes and royal recognition that legitimized this particular form of private violence and distinguished it from that of the unruly mob. The noble caste through their martial education and upbringing remained attuned to the demands of warfare. But this is a picture that was further complicated by the religious developments of the sixteenth century that established, and through royal edicts legitimized, religious difference and co-existence. (summary taken from:      Past and Present (2012) 214 (suppl 7): 275-286. doi: 10.1093/pastj/gtr032)

Author: Shagan, Ethan H.
Title: Popular Politics and the English Reformation
Abstract Note: This book is a study of popular responses to the English Reformation. It takes as its subject not the conversion of English subjects to a new religion but rather their political responses to a Reformation perceived as an act of state and hence, like all early modern acts of state, negotiated between government and people. These responses included not only resistance but also significant levels of accommodation, co-operation and collaboration as people attempted to co-opt state power for their own purposes. This study argues, then, that the English Reformation was not done to people, it was done with them in a dynamic process of engagement between government and people. As such, it answers the twenty-year-old scholarly dilemma of how the English Reformation could have succeeded despite the inherent conservatism of the English people, and it presents a genuinely post-revisionist account of one of the central events of English history.

Author: Corp, Edward
Title: The Stuart court in Exile and the Jacobites
Abstract Note: This book is about the Stuarts in continental European exile and especially about the time spent in France. Eleven researchers describe both the Paris environment of the Stuart court and the individuals who supported the exiled king James II. Apart from Sir James Montgomerei fo Skelmorlie, the books also deals with John, First Lord Caryll of Durford, the Innes Brothers, the Scots College of Paris and Roger North, historian and attorney-general of Queen Mary of Modena. An outlook to Spain is offered by Micheline Kerney Walsh who describes the travels of Toby Bourke, ambassador of James III at the court of Philip V.

Author: Oates, Jonathan D.
Title: The Jacobite Campaigns: the British State at War
Abstract Note: "The military aspects of the Jacobite campaigns in eighteenth-century Britain are considered in this study. Taken from the viewpoint of those loyal to the Hanoverian Crown, the three mailnland campaigns of 1715-16, 1719 and 1745-6 are examined, using research based on primary sources: memories, diaries, letters, newspapers and state papers. Oates looks at how the eighteenth-century military machine operated in a domestic context, as well as its effectiveness. Such a focus adds a new dimension to the study of this period, and allows for further questions as to the uniqueness of the Jacobite rebellions." In his introduction, Oates especially criticizes that Scottish history in the 18th century is generally judged by the fatal episodes of Mary Queen of Scots and Jacobitism alone. And at the same time, he wishes to see British troops in a new light. 18th century warfare in general was much better coordinated and more considerate than popular reports on brutal militia, amateur officer and helplessness in the face of Indians and patriotic rebels will allow. Oates justly attacks the image of the British troops formed by modern cinema in films such as "The Last of the Mohicans" and "The Patriot". And he hopes that rebellion in early modern times will no longer be viewed as singular and spectacular, but rather as "an occasional fact of life for the ealry modern British state, with rebellions under the Tudors, the Great Rebellion of the 1640s, the Covenanters' rebellion of 1679, the two rebellions of 1685, the 1688 invasion, the rebellions of 1689-1691, 1715, 1719 and 1745, and then the American War of 1775-81."

Author: Szechi, Daniel
Title: Professor Daniel Szechi (Subject Areas)
Publication Title: The University of Manchester: School of History, Arts and Cultures
Abstract Note: One of the most enduringly romantic images of eighteenth-century Britain is of Charles Edward Stuart ("Bonnie Prince Charlie") escaping through the heather after the battle of Culloden in 1746.  The Stuart prince and the rising associated with him have accordingly become very familiar to many who know little else about British history.  Yet nearly thirty years previously there was a larger, potentially much more threatening, Jacobite revolt against the Hanoverian regime.  From September 1715 to February 1716 most of Scotland and, for a time, parts of northern England rose in arms against the political order that had prevailed since 1688.  Two major battles were fought, one on Sheriffmuir near Dunblane and another on the streets of Preston in Lancashire, in which well over a thousand lives were lost.  In the aftermath dozens of captured rebels were executed, hundreds more transported to be sold into indentured servitude in the American and Caribbean colonies, northern Scotland was comprehensively looted and the Catholic community in northern England was judicially ransacked and intimidated. And it is the '15 that is the subject of my latest book, 1715.  The Great Jacobite Rising (Yale University Press, 2006).  It takes in all three kingdoms and the Jacobite diaspora in Europe with a view to exploring how the rebels persuaded themselves that they had come to the right time and place to overthrow the prevailing political order, and the fundamental social dynamics of the rebellion, in terms of who commanded, who obeyed and why they thought challenging the military might of the contemporary British state was feasible.  I also investigated the processes of creating a shadow-state in rebel-held areas and how the Jacobites trained and armed their troops.  The proof of the pudding in war is, though, who wins and who loses, so I also took a close look at the military clashes which gave the rising its beginning and end.  Taken in the round, there is nothing that better exposes the pathology of a society than upheaval and the shattering of verities, and, in particular, the way civil order is reasserted in its aftermath can tell us a great deal about how the machine worked.  Hence that is where the book concludes, with an analysis of the reknitting of the social order once the war was over.

Title: Atterbury Plot
Abstract Note: The Atterbury Plot was a conspiracy led by Francis Atterbury, Bishop of Rochester and Dean of Westminster, aimed at the restoration of the House of Stuart to the throne of Great Britain. It came some years after the unsuccessful Jacobite Rising of 1715, at a time when the Whig government of the new Hanoverian king was deeply unpopular.

Author: Tayler, Alistair Norwich; Tayler, Helen Agnes Henrietta
Title: The Stuart papers at Windsor : being selections from hitherto unprinted royal archives
Abstract Note: This collection covers both the 1715 and the 1745 rebellions, but there is a special focus on the Earl of Mar and Queen Clementina. Possibly the most exciting letter in this collection is a printing demand send by Prince Charles Edward to "Edgar", ten days before he started for Scotland: "I send you here also enclosed an authenthick copy of what is to be printed & dispersed at my landing." Another very exciting letter is a touching fatherly address by James Francis to his son, written on April 12, 1746 (page 168): "I will not deprieve myself of the satisfaction of writing to you at least every week, My Dearest Carluccio, tho' I am still without that of hearing directly from you. (...) tho' the truth is, it is very hard for any thing or any body to come to you, now that you are upon your retreat, and that it is not known where you may be. (...) My chief concern at present is for you personal safety, but I trust in God he will always preserve and protect you, whatever may happen." The next letter, written on May 30, 1746, refers to uncertain news of the Battle of Culloden and shows James Francis's increased concern for his son, and his growing disappointed in the French and Spanish. "There is something incomprehensible in the conduct of the Court of France in that particular that I am tyred of thinking of it and I shall say no more of it here, but that I still hope you will be allowed to make it, if you are not better emplayed, and that in all events, after all that is past, all the world must see that you have done your part, and in that respect we may rest satisfied." (p. 170) The Pretender's idea of loyalty among (Catholic) rulers and his diplomatic values seem to contrast with the opportunism of the French court, while he is still fully convinced of his family's duty to labour for the best interest of Great Britain: "The happiness of our Country must undoubtedly be your motive, and by consequence you would never surely restrict that happiness to your own life only, but endeavour to perpetuate it by a succession of Lawful Kings, who may have no other interest but those of Our Country." (Letter to Prince Charles on December 30, 1750, page 217)  James Francis generally shows great love for the Scots in particular, but whenever he talks of politics in more universal terms, he always refers to England AND Scotland as "Our Country". His sons "way of living" in 1750 and the lack of wife and heir for Charles Edward deeply worries James Francis and threatens the family tradition also in moral respects. The growing division between father and son, however, is countered by positive events such as the conversion of Lord Dunbar to Catholicism, which is cheerfully announced to James Edgar on September 23, 1751 (page 219), "hoping that the news would give his Majesty some pleasure, on account of the goodness yr Majesty was pleased to show me during the course of many years which I had the honour to pass in your service." This again reveals how individual and culturally relevant rather than politically effective Jacobitism after 1746 was. Men still adhering to it after the Battle of Culloden probably saw it as a way to reconcile a life style which was not considered "English" at home with their own true love for their home country. This outlook may have helped to bring about Catholic Relief and Catholic Emancipation on the long run, granting non-Anglican believes a proper place within English society. At the same time, later Jacobitism was marked by a decisive new internationalism, wittily expressed in Lord Dunbar's own writing: "It is certaine that we whome providence has conducted into Catholique countrys and obliged to live and probably to dy in them are of all me the most unexcusable if we neglect to examine seriously the grounds of the separation of our ancestors from the Universal church, and a serious examen can never divert you from the truth if you are in the right way, because, as you well know besides the force of truth itself education, habit and in spite of all resolutions to the contrary a strong prevention on their side." (page 219) For further study, it will be necessary and interesting to look at the definitions of "the Royal Cause" given by Sir Richard Warren, Major General to James Francis, too. In a letter from Vannes on May 6, 1760, he thanked James Francis for granting him new military commission even though this might not be put into action. (page 252) So how did he see his role in Jacobitism? And what purpose did it all serve as late as 1760? The final section of the book (APPENDIX) is dedicated to petitions to the "King in Rome" and how James Francis dealt with them. It is interesting that people actually expected support from a king without a crown, and this communication may shed further light on the strong personal ties between the Stuarts and their supporters. Especially in comparison to the American Revolution, the petitions may reveal a general demand for broader participation in political procedures of the time, and they might also reveal people's displeasure with law enforcement and the execution of justice at home. Strong and efficient PARALLEL STRUCTURES of legislature and justice were one of the main causes for the successful American Independence. This is why the petitions to James Francis Stuart are well worth looking at.
Manual Tags: House of Stuart.; Jacobites; James, 1688-1766, Prince of Wales.

Author: Corp, Edward
Title: The king over the water. Portraits of the Stuarts in exile after 1689
Abstract Note: The book is the official exhibition catalogue published by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in 2001. The exhibition was sponsored by famous Scottish whisky company 'Drambuie' because they date their whisky-based liqueur back to Prince Charles Edward Stuart (page 6). Drambuie finance both research and collecting in order to re-assess Jacobitism within British and European politics and culture. Edward Corp's exhibition catalogue, however, does not give any new or exciting interpretations of the Stuart portraits from Italy and France. Corp's text is a thorough study of the timeframe of portrait production in exile - and it states how difficult it often is to attribute a particular painting to one of the many artists engaged by the Stuart family; but the political iconography of the official Stuart portraits and the variations in content and style which mark the cheaper copies circulated all across Europe are not described suffienctly. Edward Corp rather dwells on the popular attraction exerted by the "romance, the heroism (...) and the ultimate tragedy of Scotland's exiled royal family". (page 11) Even though the coloured reproductions of the portraits can very well enlarge our picture database, the book leaves much to be desired.
Publisher: The Trustees of the National Galleries of Scotland

Author: The Historical Association
Title: The myths about the 1745 Jacobite revolution - The Historical Association
Publication Title: The Historical Association - The voice for history
Abstract Note: The 1745 Rebellion has become part of the romantic heritage in both British and Scottish history. At the time there was little romance to it. The many myths and misconceptions about Bonnie Prince Charlie and his followers need to be corrected and the glamorous image of the Rebellion eradicated. The harsh reality of the Rebellion is typified by the scene on a January day after the Battle of Falkirk. The white bodies of the dead and the dying lay on the hillside above the town, stripped of their clothing and resembling sheep.

Title: The ghostly figures of Roger Mortimer, William de Roches, Hubert de Burg, Simon Montfort, and Robert Devereux approach a seated Sawney Macintosh who tries to move away from them.
Abstract Note: Sawney sits beneath a draped canopy in highland costume. Two books entitled 'North Briton' and 'Monitor' lie on a table beside Sawney. The figures are labelled A-F and described in the text below. The ghosts appear amidst a cloud of smoke at their feet with speech bubbles that refer to their status. Sawney retorts 'By St Andrew these ill far'd ghoists gar my blood run cauld with horror! gin I were safe in my own country. Ise be content to feed on bannocks & haggies as I were want to do.' Beside him another speech bubble urges 'Fly Sawney to the middle of Wallachia & in its blissful vales forget your fears.' On the walls behind are two oval framed pictures, including one of Bonnie Prince Charlie, the Young Pretender, on the right? One of many caricatures of the Highlanders during the Highland rebellion of 1745
Automatic Tags: Scotland; Jacobites; Caricatures; Sawney

Author: Manley, Mary Delariviere
Title: A true relation of the several facts and circumstances of the intended riot and tumult on Queen Elizabeth's birth-day: Gathered from authentick accounts: and published for the information of all true lovers of our constitution in Church and State
Abstract Note: Writer, 1670-1724, born in Jersey or at sea between Jersey and Guernsey, daughter of a royalist army officer and historian, Tory family, acquainted with Jonathan Swift, published letters, play 'The Lost Lover', tragedy, poems, public controversy in print with Steele, editor of the Female Tatler, 'From 1711 to 1713 Manley concentrated on political journalism, editing Jonathan Swift's Examiner for number 7 (14 September 1710) and numbers 46 to 42 (14 June to 26 July 1711). These contained a series of direct attacks on whig propaganda, but are without the female narrative frames or striking female protagonists that are her trade mark in prose fiction and drama. (...) Manley's liaison with the Jacobite printer and alderman of the City of London John Barber may have begun as early as 1705  when he published her Queen Zarah. (...) With Queen Anne's death in 1714 and the decline of tory hopes, Manley seems to have turned away from partisan publication without losing her relish for scandal. (...) Her clear-sighted exposure of sexual double standards, if leavened with sexual voyeurism and a taste for the scandalous and perverse, reveals her to be an early exponent of Enlightenment feminism.' (DNB, Volume 36, p. 423)

Author: Genet-Rouffiac, Nathalie; France. Service historique de la défense.
Title: Le grand exil. Les jacobites en France, 1688-1715
Abstract Note: In this long volume of 702 pages, the story of the Stuart court in France from the Glorious Revolution to the Jacobite Rebellion of 1715 is explained in great detail and with open sympathy for the exiled dynasty. The author's focus rests on the effective social, military and political networks which the Stuarts and their supporters have managed to create all across Europe: "Le jacobitisme ne reste pas une nébuleuse de conspirateurs ou d'exilés nostalgiques. Il s'appuie sur des institutions religieuses, à Paris en particulier, que décrit bien Nathalie Genet-Rouffiac, il mobilise des solidarités et tisse des réseaux à travers l'Europe. Même si les premières générations ont eu la sensation de connaître l'échec dans leurs entreprises, les Jacobites ont su utiliser leurs épreuves comme une force afin d'entreprendre encore et, à la fin, pour utiliser des métaphores communes, le déracinement devient fertile, la transplantation féconde. Nombre de Jacobites s'illustrent partout en Europe comme généraux, négociateurs, hommes d'Etat, banquiers, commerÇants. Au-delà des solidarités qu'ils entretiennent, les milieux jacobites élaborent peut-être une culture commune qu'inspire la nostalgie du pays natal, l'attente du retour des Stuart et la renaissance d'un monde perdu. Est-ce trop dire que l'on retrouve là les traits d'une diaspora?" (Lucien Bély, Université Paris-Sorbonne)
Num Pages: 701 p. : ill. (some col.), facsim., geneal. tables, maps, ports. ; 25 cm.

Author: Asch, Ronald G.
Title: Die Stuarts. Geschichte einer Dynastie
Abstract Note: In regard to the jacobite rebellions in the 18th century, Asch does not share the idea that the Stuart dynasty was nothing but old-fashioned and blind to the political needs of the day. Asch stresses some modern, open-minded tendencies of the Stuart court life in exile, e.g. the intense contact with Protestant theologians. Furthermore, Charles Edward Stuart did not approve of his brother Henry's decision to become a priest and cardinal. For Charles Edward, a good accord with the Protestant Englishmen was a necessary basis for his attempts to regain the British crown. And he was very well aware that Great Britain could never be converted to Catholicism again. This is why Daniel Szechi, too, may have a point in seeing the jacobites as witty diplomats and true 'Europeans'. And most of the recent literature on the Stuarts in seems to share this very positive view. The ways in which the jacobites interpreted rebellion, legitimate resistance and a proper state constitution, however, are hardly ever discussed.
Manual Tags: Great Britain; England; King of England; Rulers; France; Church And State; Catholicism; Protestantism; Scotland; exile; Jacobite; Stuart; monarchy; Italy; religious minority; religious freedom; tolerance

Title: The National Archive of the UK SP 90/2/15
Abstract Note: Folio 15: Raby to Nottingham. Meeting with the resident of Hanover [Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz] who complained about Frederick I's conduct. Another audience with Frederick: king of Portugal [Peter II] has acknowledged Frederick's royalty; Queen Anne's desire for anend to the Lüneburg-Prussian feud, especially in view of ominous developments in the Empire; Frederick's continued anger over the occupation of Hildesheim; Antonius Ulrich's relations with France; reasons for Frederick's distrust of Lüneburg. Lüneburg dislikes Prussian occupation of Nordhausen. Wartenberg has requested Raby to consider the Prussian and the Hanoverian cases together. Denmark and Prussia allied against Sweden and Lüneburg; French envoys contribute to the difficulties at both courts. From Berlin

Title: Jacobite Epilogue. A Further Selection of Letters from Jacobites among the Stuart papers at Windsor. Published by the Gracious Permission of His Majesty the King, edited, with an introduction by Henrietta Tayer, F.R.Hist.S.
Abstract Note: This collection of letters focuses on the aftermath of the fatal 1745 rebellion and especially aims to display the negative influence of Irish advisors on Charles Edward and the Prince's own inability to accept and communicate his loss to his supporters. The letters focus on the adherents' petitions and expressions of loyalty rather than the responses given by James Francis and Charles Edward, which is why the overall impression is that of a very one-sided, increasingly disappointed contact. Considering the 'long-durée' effects, this collection outlines the failure of Jacobitism as a story of personal inability and mismanagement, but I rather feel that the problems of miscommunication after 1745 were not foreseeable as such. James Francis did very well in his international networking through many private letters and a very efficient 'royal performance' even though he may not have been a viliant military leader. His son Charles Edward had the opposite qualities but could rely on his father's friends. This is why personal weaknesses on either side may have mattered much less than the editors of many Jacobite letters wish to suggest. Instead of a complete failure, the later Jacobite movement must rather be described as a matter of transformation. After 1746, it was no longer a military movement and maybe not even a monarchical movement. The centre of attention shifted from the Pretender and the Prince towards cultural and constitutional matters. And this shift has certainly proved even more fruitful for the idea of opposition in England and Scotland than the ealier attempts to restore the Stuart monarchy by force. Especially the letters by Lord George Murray written after Aprul 17, 1746, are very revealing for this cause (cf. pages 63 etc.). The most important letter expressing James Francis's feelings and helplessness after Culloden was written on January 20, 1747, and addressed to John Cameron Lochiel (page 133 and 134). Evidence of ciphered letters is given on pages 132 and 133, which contain a letter from Lochiel to the Prine in February 1745. In this letter, the address "YRH" as well as references to place, time and people involved in the uprising are given as a number code.
Place: London, Edinburgh, Paris, Melbourne, Toronto and New York

Title: Jacobite letters to Lord Pitsligo 1745-1746. Preserved at Fettercairn House, edited with notes by Alistair and Henrietty Tayler
Abstract Note: This volumes contains the correspondence of Jacobite Lords in Scotland. The major themes of their letters are: 1. seeking military support (abroad) 2. protecting the Prince against procalamtions of apprehension by King George II (reward for catching Charles Edward dead or alive) 3. raising money among fellow Scotsmen for a march into England 4. justifying their levying of "civil war" A letter from October 4, 1745, reveals that the Jacobites were just as afraid of assassins and religious fanatics as the Hanoverians were (page 34), and letters from Charled Edward to his officers show the emphasis generally placed on "the Rules and Discipline of war" by 18th century aristocratic armies (page 38). An interesting piece is the French perspective on the war given in the "Declaration of Lord John Drummond, Commander in chief of his most Christian Majesties forces in Scotland", which addresses Charles Edward only as "Regent of Scotland" and declares "England" the enemy. (page 47) This idea of a war of two nations may not have pleased the majority of Jacobites, who tended to consider the rebellion a "civil war" for just succession within Britain. In a letter to Lord Pitsligo on January 23, 1746, Dr. Leechman, Professor at Glasgow, adopted the idea of a 'civil war' as follows: "From what I know of your Lordship's character I am persuaded that you are fully sensible of the many unavoidable calamities of a Civil war and that you will prevent all such miseries as may be avoided. I hope that the distress which the detaining these four deserving young men may occasion to themselves, to their relations and those with whom they are connected will prevail with you to use your Interest for their speedy release." (page 49) The practice of petitioning for prisoners of war is further described in a letter by Reverend James Robb from Kilsyth to Lord Pitsligo in January 1746. (page 51) In a letter dated February 1746, Lord George Murray refers to the King's troops as "the enemy" in a very rational and unemotional report to Lord Pitsligo. (page 53) Besides, George Murray shows great concern for the local population: "If your Lop. approve of it I would pay a reasonable price for carages & indeavour to save the poor peoples horse as much as possible." (page 57)  This links the Jacobites very much to the American Revolutionaries and their strong local support in New England. In late February, the Scots hear of 4000 Hessians being in Leith road "by Letters intercepted". (page 65) Problems of cash and supplies shortly before the crucial Battle of Culloden are mentioned in pages 72 and 73! Even though soldiers could not be paid in cash, however, receipts were carefully kept and the military leaders were eager to "assure the proprietors that his R.H. will pay them so soon as the state of affairs will permit." (page 73) Lord Pitsligo to John Murray, February 26, 1746: "Circumstances must determine whether we shall make head against the Enemy, or make an honourable Retreat should they advance upon us with a superior force." (page 75) John Murray on February 28, 1746: "I believe it might be very necessary to have a quantity of straw and fire provided in case the Prince send any more troops his way, but without a certainty I should be sorry to harass the country too much." (page 78) VERY IMPORTANT, page 85: "The following account of a Court Martial held at Elgin is curious as showing that even in this time of stress (March 1746), proper military procedure and discipline in the Prince's army were still maintained." page 93: transferring prisoners savely to Inverness ... "for we do not know how long we will be eable to keep this post". Lord Pitsligo's answer to Sir Thomas Sheridan from Elgin, April 8, 1746: "There were fifteen horses more sent from this place today recommended to that Coll; which is such a burden upon this Country that a great many of the Farmers will be incapacitated from tilling their ground their familys consequently reduced to Beggary. I'm sure it was allways the Prince's intention (since hardships must be) that none should suffer beyond their proportion (...) and every body wishes that orders of any consequence were only given to such persons as are acquainted with the laws of the Country." (page 113) Sir Thomas Sheridan to Lord Pitsligo, April ye 9th, 1746: "My Lord, Yr. Ldp. nor no body else need doubt but H.R.H. is concern'd at any dammage done in a country which he came not to oppress but set free. Yet still it must be remembered that War always carrys such accidents along with it and tho' H.R.H. wou'd never be persuaded to allow of such things, yet his ennemies cou'd have no just reason to complain if he did, considering with what barbarity the Elector's forces and Partizans have treated our friends, by burning the houses and stripping the women and children wherever they could come." (page 115) IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CENSORSHIP OF PRO-GOVERNMENT LETTERS BY JACOBITE LEADERS: page 116. Equally important: page 120 and 121: Lady Dunbar wishes to travel to Aberdeen, occupied by the Duke of Cumberland. Fearing that she might "give intelligence", Lord Pitsligo hinders her journey and only upon her promise not to reveal military details, she receives permission to travel in early April 1746.  The last letter of the present collection was written on APRIL 11, 1746, FROM SPEYMOUTH and anticipates battle with the "enemy" (page 124). Cumberland's army crossed the Spey on that day without opposition. Charles Edward had obviously hoped to "dispute the passage of the river", but Lord George Murray was against it. There is no attempt of negotiation on either side. "Upon the 12th and 13th of April Cumberland's army quartered on the west side of the spey, on Lord Braco's lands (and Lord Braco, in spite of his Whig principles, afterwards made an extensive claim for damages)." (page 126) On April 15, the Highlanders made their fatal attempt to overcome Cumberland's troops at Culloden.

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/60/136v: To Consbruch
Abstract Note: Folio 136v. To Consbruch. Commends the patriotism of Consbruch and of Leibniz. - Does not wish to name anyone in particular but finds the court of Dresden less than edifying. - The elector is in deep mourning for the late countess [Rochlitz] and is making everyone else at court do likewise. - Dresden hopes the imperial court will pay over the remaining two thirds of the 50,000 écus [subsidies] promised and trusts that England and the States will insist this be done. He, Stepney, and Ham have twice sought to reassure the elector on this point. [Draft].   Date and Place: 1694 Apr 8 O.S.
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: State Papers Foreign, Archives of British Legations

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/60/71: To Schweinfurt
Abstract Note: Folio 71. To Schweinfurt. Acknowledges letter of Nov 13 [?Style] Should he see Leibniz, he will hear from him that he, Stepney, wrote him 'above 8 months ago' that 'the elector of Bavaria would be contented with the heavenly life of Bruxelles & not think of another marriage; and I am persuaded ye princesse will find it so at long run'. - Reference to Ilten's arrival at Dresden and its possible consequences: payment of outstanding subsidies by Brandenburg and Hessen-Cassel. Remainder similar to f.70v. PS: About cipher: 'The figure 90 may stand for the first person; for now my lord N[ottingham] is displeased wee shall have no occasion of making any mention of him'. - If he knows anything about the reasons of Devaulx's dismissal (see f.66v, ante), Plantamour, a co-religionist, would be grateful for information. Date and Place: 1693 Dec 1/11 Dresden
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: State Papers Foreign, Archives of British Legations

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/58/33v: Stepney to [Gottfried Wilhelm] Leibniz, 'counseiller de la Cour a Hannovre'
Abstract Note: Folio 33v. Stepney to [Gottfried Wilhelm] Leibniz, 'counseiller de la Cour a Hannovre'. Describes the welcome he had received from other diplomats accredited to the imperial court at Vienna. Expresses his delight that [Sophia] the consort of Ernest Augustus, duke of Hanover, through his recent elevation to the [ninth] electorate, has now become electress; and hopes that she, of blood royal [being the twelfth child of Elizabeth, queen of Bohemia] may, like her daughter [Sophia Charlotte, consort of Elector Frederick of Brandenburg], perpetuate royalty. Appends Latin verses with an English rendering thereof. Date and Place: 1693 Feb 4 Vienna
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: State Papers Foreign, Archives of British Legations

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/60/100: To Leibniz. Thanks him for letter received [date not given]
Abstract Note: Folio 100. To Leibniz. Thanks him for letter received [date not given]. Had wished to write before but waited until he had something of substance to impart. Mourns the demise of Strattmann and Grote.-The false pregnancy of the electoress is a victory for the countess [Rochlitz]. The elector is going first to Torgau and thence to the Leipzig fair. Hoym has been released. Schöning is being brought to Vienna, it is said he may change his religion. [Corrected draft].   Date and Place: 1694 Dec 29/Jan 8 Dresden
Archive: The National Archives of the UK, Kew
Archive Location: State Papers Foreign, Archives of British Legations

Author: TNA
Title: SP 105/60/108v: To [George Michael] Backmeister [Hanoverian chargé d'affaires at Berlin]
Abstract Note: Folio 108v. To [George Michael] Backmeister [Hanoverian chargé d'affaires at Berlin]. Acknowledges letter of Sept 17 forwarded to him from Vienna. Mainly private: comparing notes on amorous experiences. Presumes that Backmeister has returned to Hanover. Wishes to beremembered to Leibniz. Reference to the death of Strattmann and Grote [Sept 15]. Author: National Library of Scotland
Title: Blaikie.SNPG.9.17 - Agreeable Contrast between the formidable John of Grant and Don Carlos of Southern Extraction (1749)
Abstract Note: Satire Potrait of Prince Charles sitting at desk with room full of books, and a Classical woman behind him, saying "Lo! Mars triumphant at thy Sacred Feet, courting a Brim to an unhallowed sheet" Prince Charles is reading books, the Magna Charta is on the desk, and a piece of paper with the text "Mars and Venus have conspired to quell him of which anon I shall not fail to tell him". Author: National Library of Scotland
Title: Special and Named Printed Collections in the National Library of Scotland: WALTER BLAIKIE COLLECTION
Publication Title: National Library of Scotland / Leabharlann Nàiseanta na h-Alba
Abstract Note: Formed by Dr Walter Biggar Blaikie (1847-1928) of the Edinburgh printing firm of T. & A. Constable, and presented by his daughters in 1928, this collection is devoted to the Stuart and Jacobite period, 1688-1746. Blaikie was a recognized authority on the history of Jacobitism, and his collection of 1,076 printed items in 756 volumes, 42 manuscripts, three charters and c. 400 engravings relate to the attempts of the House of Stuart to reinstate itself on the throne of Great Britain. There is a good representation of polemical pamphlet literature on the controversy over the birth of James IIýs son in 1689, and the associated political questions of allegiance and legitimacy; historical works on the course of the Risings of 1715 and 1745 are complemented by contemporary poems, satires and sermons, many in French; and there are accounts of the trials, executions and expropriations that followed both Risings with the Government viewpoint recorded in the numerous Session Papers and Acts of Parliament concerned with these matters. There are also 22 portfolios of engravings of the Royal House of Stuart - portraits, views, broadsides, and caricatures - which have been placed by the National Library on long-term deposit in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. A small number of engravings have been retained in the Libraryýs collection.

Author: Szechi, Daniel
Title: A Non‐Resisting, Passively Obedient Revolution: Lord North and Grey and the Tory Response to the Sacheverell Impeachment

Author: Speck, William Arthur
Title: The Current State of Sacheverell Scholarship
Abstract Note: This article reviews the literature on the Sacheverell affair as it stood when it was delivered as a paper to the symposium held in March 2010 to commemorate the 300th anniversary of his impeachment. The basic narrative and prevalent interpretation of its significance were established by the late Geoffrey Holmes in his monograph The Trial of Doctor Sacheverell published in 1973. Holmes placed it in the context of a crisis in Church and state brought about by the Glorious Revolution and its aftermath. This led to the formation of the party conflict between high church tories and low church whigs. When the whigs, led by the junto, came to power between 1708 and 1710, their ascendancy provoked a reaction from tories claiming that the established Church was in danger. It was in this context that Sacheverell preached his provocative sermon on 5 November 1709, which brought on his impeachment for high crimes and misdemeanours. Holmes's detailed account of the trial, together with his separate analysis of the 'Sacheverell riots', have been generally accepted as definitive. Consequently, scholarly attention has tended to shift to the cultural aspects of the affair such as poems on affairs of state and political prints. These investigations have led, in turn, to attempts to establish an appropriate methodology for analysing their significance.
Automatic Tags: deists; dissenters; DISSENTERS -- Great Britain; GREAT Britain -- Church history -- 18th century; GREAT Britain -- History -- Revolution of 1688; high church; low church; NONJURORS; occasional conformity; revolution (of 1688); RIOTS -- England -- History; SACHEVERELL, Henry; tories; TORY Party (Great Britain) -- History -- 18th century; WHIG Party (Great Britain) -- History -- 18th century; whigs

Author: Knights, Mark
Title: Introduction: The View from 1710
Abstract Note: The articles in this volume, planned to mark the tercentenary of the impeachment of Dr Henry Sacheverell on 23 March 1710, reassess the importance of his trial. Sacheverell's attack on the revolution of 1688, and the principles which underpinned it, allows us to question how far, 20 years later, a whig revolution had prevailed. The articles suggest that the revolution continued to be contested; that in 1710 the high church tory vision temporarily triumphed; that the flood of print showed the importance of religious dispute in shaping the public sphere; that the debate over Sacheverell connected Westminster and the public, not just in England but also in Ireland; that there was an important disagreement between high and low church about how to respond to the press's licentiousness, part of a story about the shift away from prepublication censorship towards regulation of print and copyright; that the print controversy over the trial was vituperative, 'impolite' and traded lies and misrepresentations; that Sacheverell's critics sought to associate him with harlots in a bid to suggest that his strong influence over women was unhealthy; that Sacheverell, on the other hand, deliberately depicted himself as a martyr; and that, for all its religious heat, 1710 was also important for an early enlightenment debate about political economy, since the tory vision on Church and state also embraced a reoriented foreign policy and that this contest over imperial visions had important consequences for the development of the colonies after 1714.
Automatic Tags: Ireland; gender; Sacheverell; GREAT Britain -- History -- Revolution of 1688; SACHEVERELL, Henry; censorship; CENSORSHIP -- Great Britain -- History; early enlightenment; empire; Glorious Revolution; GREAT Britain -- Colonies -- History; GREAT Britain -- History -- Anne, 1702-1714; GREAT Britain -- History -- William & Mary, 1689-1702; ideology; moderation; political economy; press; PRESS & politics -- History; PUBLIC sphere
